result.execSummary:
The defendant Eric C. Romanski was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Battery, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Consecutive to: AMENDED 9/4/14.  Consecutive only for purposes of sentence credit.
Concurrent with: AMENDED 9/4/14.  Concurrent with any probation now serving.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
Attend and successfully complete alcohol assessment and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.
Defendant must attend and successfully complete a drug assessment  and comply with any recommended treatment.  Defendant to execute any releases necessary for agent to verify compliance.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  Obey all no contact orders of his agent.

Defendant is to submit to testing at the Jackson County Sheriff's Dept. 3 times per week.    The defendant shall cooperate with and participate in any assessments, treatment and/or programming as determined appropriate based on the defendant's assessed risk and criminogenic needs, and as directed by the Department of Corrections. To include CGIP and anger management, if agent requires.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Eric C. Romanski

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: from Judge Goodman to Attorneys Inlow & Betthauser
Bond modified as follows:  stay the SCRAM unit requirement and allow Eric Romanski to attend doctor appointments on June 27, 2014; July 3, 2014; July 7, 2014; and July 23, 2014.
Plea hearing on July 9, 2014 at 11:00 am.
Subpoena and Certificate of Appearance served on Deputy Adam Olson for appearance at prelim on May 9
Subpoena and Certificate of Appearance served on Deputy Justin Wathke at Prelim on 5-09-14
Preliminary hearing on May 9, 2014 at 02:00 pm.

Until further order of the court, you shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, except through your attorney, with any of the following individuals: Victim P.V., Ryan M. or Elizabeth M.    Defendant shall not consume any alcohol unless a physician states in writing that the defendant is alcohol dependent and complete withdrawal could endanger the defendant's health or life. In this case a doctor's excuse must be submitted to the Jackson County Clerk of Court or the Jackson County Jail within 48 hours of the bond being signed. Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, bar areas of restaurants, or where available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.  As a condition of your release, you must be available 24 hours per day, 7 days a week to submit to testing for alcohol when requested by a law enforcement officer or your probation agent. The defendant may submit to an alcohol test at the Jackson County Sheriff's Office or submit to a PBT by a law enforcement officer. Upon request, the defendant shall appear for and submit to testing within two (2) hours of the official's request.  Not to possess any firearms.
